verses.text: When Solomon finished praying, fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offering and the sacrifices, and the glory of the LORD filled the temple.
verses.comment: The rendering is direct. 'Temple' is used for 'house of the LORD' for clarity.

verses.text: The priests could not enter the temple of the LORD because the glory of the LORD filled it.
verses.comment: Phrase clarified for readability; literal meaning preserved.

verses.text: When all the people of Israel saw the fire come down and the glory of the LORD over the temple, they bowed down with their faces to the ground on the pavement, and worshiped and thanked the LORD, saying, "He is good; his love endures forever."
verses.comment: Literal, with 'his love endures forever' matching the standard refrain.

verses.text: Then the king and all the people offered sacrifices before the LORD.
verses.comment: Wording is kept straightforward and literal.

verses.text: King Solomon offered as a sacrifice twenty-two thousand oxen and one hundred twenty thousand sheep. So the king and all the people dedicated the temple of God.
verses.comment: Numerical values unaltered; 'temple of God' per literal rendering.

verses.text: The priests stood at their posts, as did the Levites with the instruments for music to the LORD that King David had made for giving thanks to the LORD—for his love endures forever—whenever David praised by their ministry. The priests blew trumpets before them, and all Israel stood.
verses.comment: Clarifies role of Levites with musical instruments. 'For his love endures forever' is the repeated refrain from David.

verses.text: Solomon consecrated the middle of the courtyard in front of the temple of the LORD, because there he offered burnt offerings and the fat of the fellowship offerings—since the bronze altar Solomon had made could not hold the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat portions.
verses.comment: Clarifies why the courtyard was used for offerings.

verses.text: At that time Solomon kept the feast for seven days, and all Israel with him—a very great assembly, from Lebo-Hamath to the Brook of Egypt.
verses.comment: 'Lebo-Hamath' and 'Brook of Egypt' are kept as geographic markers.

verses.text: On the eighth day, they held a solemn assembly, for they had celebrated the dedication of the altar for seven days and the feast for seven days.
verses.comment: Logic clarified: two seven-day events, then an eighth day assembly.

verses.text: On the twenty-third day of the seventh month, he sent the people away to their homes, joyful and glad of heart for the goodness the LORD had shown to David, Solomon, and his people Israel.
verses.comment: Modernized order—joyful and glad of heart for God’s goodness.

verses.text: So Solomon finished the temple of the LORD and the king’s palace, and successfully completed everything that he had planned to do in the temple of the LORD and in his own palace.
verses.comment: Phrase matches original order for both house and palace.

verses.text: Then the LORD appeared to Solomon at night and said to him, "I have heard your prayer and have chosen this place for myself as a house of sacrifice."
verses.comment: Direct translation; clarifies God’s choice of the site for sacrifice.

verses.text: "When I shut up the heavens so that there is no rain, or command the locusts to devour the land, or send a plague among my people,"
verses.comment: List-style preserved; 'shut up the heavens' kept as per original.

verses.text: "if my people, who are called by my name, humble themselves and pray and seek my face and turn from their wicked ways, then I will hear from heaven, and I will forgive their sin and heal their land."
verses.comment: Faithful to the often-quoted original; 'heal their land' preserved.

verses.text: "Now my eyes will be open and my ears attentive to the prayers offered in this place."
verses.comment: Eyes and ears rendered literally; 'this place' = temple.

verses.text: "For I have now chosen and consecrated this temple so that my name may be there forever. My eyes and my heart will always be there."
verses.comment: 'Temple' substituted for 'house'; 'forever' matches original intent.

verses.text: "And as for you, if you walk before me as your father David walked, doing everything I have commanded you and keeping my statutes and my judgments,"
verses.comment: Direct quote; 'walk before me' retained as idiom.

verses.text: "then I will establish your royal throne, just as I covenanted with your father David, saying, 'You will never fail to have a man to rule over Israel.'"
verses.comment: Modernized language in the promise of dynasty.

verses.text: "But if you turn away and forsake my statutes and my commands that I have set before you, and go and serve other gods and worship them,"
verses.comment: Faithful, with 'forsake' as per original wording.

verses.text: "then I will uproot you from my land which I have given you, and I will reject this temple which I have consecrated for my name, and I will make it a proverb and a byword among all peoples."
verses.comment: 'Uproot' and 'byword' retain original idiom.

verses.text: "And though this temple is now exalted, everyone who passes by it will be appalled and will say, 'Why has the LORD done such a thing to this land and to this temple?'"
verses.comment: Rendered plainly; original language is preserved.

verses.text: "And people will answer, 'Because they abandoned the LORD, the God of their ancestors, who brought them out of the land of Egypt, and they embraced other gods and worshiped and served them. That is why he brought all this disaster on them.'"
verses.comment: Comment explains the judgment and cause; faithful to the original meaning.
